conclusion: To compare internal energy at states a and c, understand processes and properties of an ideal gas.
Diagram shows two adiabatic processes (curved lines) and two isochoric processes (vertical lines).
Adiabatic processes involve no heat exchange (Q = 0).
For adiabatic process, PV^γ = constant, and ΔU = -W.
In isochoric process, W = 0 and ΔU = Q.
Internal energy U of an ideal gas depends on temperature T: U = nC_vT.
To compare internal energies at a and c, compare their temperatures.
State c is at higher pressure and presumably higher volume than state a.
Moving from c to b is isochoric, so temperature at c and b is the same.
Moving from b to a is adiabatic; temperature at a is lower than at b (and c).
Internal energy at state c is greater than at state a because temperature at c is higher.
Final answer: Internal energy at state c is greater than at state a.
